The Chandler Asian Festival is a celebration of Asian culture and heritage with this mission statement: Our mission is to cultivating culture through collaboration and stand strong as one. 

We chose the Tiger because Tigers stand for strength, power, courage, and ambition. The animal represents a symbolic release of fears and standing for truth, justice, and integrity.

Last year was very challenging but with the help from the communities, volunteers,vendors , performers, Mayor Kevin Hartke and especially from Niki Tapia and her team from the diversity group, our 2021 Chandler Asian Festival was a success. 

We are working hard to make 2022 Chandler Asian Festival a even more of a success, and with your help, we will.

column38:
For those traveling East and West on Hwy 84 through Fairfield today - 
                    PLEASE BE ADVISED

Hwy 84, known as Commerce Street in the Fairfield city limits, will be closed during the Freestone County Parade. The parade will start at 7pm sharp and should conclude around 8:30pm.
During this time, there will be a detour route set up in order for traffic to continue moving safely.
The following information is being provided to better assist you with your travels : 
Detour for those traveling West to East:
* From Fairfield take Hwy 75 South to FM 489. Take FM 489 all the way until you get back to East Hwy 84. 
* From Teague take FM 179 all the way to Dew where it meets FM 489 at the 4-Way Stop. Take FM 489 all the way until you get back to East Hwy 84.(Unless your destination is on Hwy 75 in or towards Fairfield) 

Detour for those traveling East to West:
* From Butler/Oakwood take FM 489 and follow FM 489 all the way to the 4-Way Stop in Dew. At this point you can take Hwy 75 North toward Fairfield or you can take FM 179 from Dew to Teague.

** We recommend all semi, big trucks and trailers, and any oversized loads find a safe place to pull over or park until the main roads through Fairfield are open back up. We prefer you be in a parking lot of a hotel, restaurant, or truck stop in order for remaining traffic to continue to flow safely.

** FM 1580, known as Post Oak Road, is closed to through traffic due to bridge maintenance. This is not a detour route and you will not be able to get through. 

** Deputies will be located in Dew at the 4-Way Stop to control traffic and assist if needed.

column38:
I am heartbroken today. 

I am heartbroken for people around this country who just lost the fundamental right to make informed decisions about their own bodies.

I am heartbroken that we may now be destined to learn the painful lessons of a time before Roe was made law of the land‚Äîa time when women risked losing their lives getting illegal abortions. A time when the government denied women control over their reproductive functions, forced them to move forward with pregnancies they didn‚Äôt want, and then abandoned them once their babies were born. 

That is what our mothers and grandmothers and great-grandmothers lived through, and now here we are again. 

So yes, I am heartbroken‚Äîfor the teenage girl, full of zest and promise, who won‚Äôt be able to finish school or live the life she wants because her state controls her reproductive decisions; for the mother of a nonviable pregnancy who is now forced to bring that pregnancy to term; for the parents watching their child‚Äôs future evaporate before their very eyes; for the health care workers who can no longer help them without risking jail time. 

When we don‚Äôt understand our history, we are doomed to repeat its mistakes. In this country, our futures are tied together in a delicate tapestry that we each have a hand in making. Too often, cynicism or indifference makes us feel like we don‚Äôt have a say in weaving it, but that couldn‚Äôt be further from the truth. The more we allow pessimism to push us further into helplessness, the less we will be empowered to help create the kind of country we want to live in.  

This horrifying decision will have devastating consequences, and it must be a wake-up call, especially to the young people who will bear its burden. I know this is not the future you chose for your generation‚Äîbut if you give up now, you will inherit a country that does not resemble you or any of the values you believe in. 

This moment is difficult, but our story does not end here. It may not feel like we are able to do much right now, but we can. And we must. 

If you‚Äôre like me and you want to get started right now, I encourage you to channel your frustration and anger into action by getting involved. Organizations like Planned Parenthood and The United State of Women, among many others, have resources you can look to if you want to help others or if you need help yourself. 

Our hearts may be broken today, but tomorrow, we‚Äôve got to get up and find the courage to keep working towards creating the more just America we all deserve. We have so much left to push for, to rally for, to speak for‚Äîand I know we can do this together.
